newsitem.title: USA: CME details new weekly cash cheese trading format.
newsitem.headline: CME details new weekly cash cheese trading format.

text.p: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said it will begin cash cheese trading on May 1 in a new format that replaces the old National Cheese Exchange (NCE) in Green Bay, Wisconsin.
Trading will take place once a week on Thursdays in a 30-minute session from 1315 to 1345 CDT (1815 to 1845 GMT), the exchange said in a statement.

A new trading pit for spot cheese at the CME will post handwritten bids and offers on dry erase boards, with the closing price determined by a call session. Pit traders will be provided with 50 telephone lines, it said.
Trading will be in contracts for 40,000 to 44,000 pounds of cheese quoted in cents per pound. Minimum price fluctuation will be $.0025 per pound or $100-110 per contract.
Delivery can be made at par within 300 miles south of Green Bay or at other points in the continental United States with a freight allowance.
Delivery can be made of cheddar cheese in 40-pound blocks or cheddar or granular cheese in 55-gallon barrels. Cheese must be at least 4 days old on the date of sales.
Ticker symbols are KB: (blocks) and RB: (barrels).
The CME said the new format was accepted by the boards of the National Cheese Institute and the National Cheese Exchange. The final day of trading at NCE will be April 25.

The switch to broker-handled cheese trading and anonymous participants at the CME comes after the NCE came under repeated criticism from Wisconsin dairy producers who claimed it was a closed forum where a few players set the national price of cheese.
